snippet: The justices do not want to hear the most versatile of the Anglo-Saxon swear words even when the case before them turns on it.
abstract: Adam Liptak Sidebar column observes that Supreme Court justices generally do not want to hear the most versatile Anglo-Saxon curse word even when the case before them turns on it; notes that with decision expected, no lawyer or justice uttered the vulgarity during a two-part court case in 2008 and 2011 examining whether the government may punish the broadcasting of four-letter words by celebrities on television.
lead_paragraph: The justices do not want to hear the most versatile of the Anglo-Saxon swear words even when the case before them turns on it.

headline.print_headline: A Word Heard Often, Except at the Supreme Court
headline.seo: A Word Heard Often, Except at the Supreme Court
headline.main: A Word Heard Often, Except at the Supreme Court
